posts.html:
Ghost themes

Ghost comes with a default theme called Casper, which is designed to be a clean, readable publication layout and can be easily adapted for most purposes.

If you need something a little more customised, it's entirely possible to build on top of existing open source themes, or to build your own from scratch. Rather than giving you a few basic settings which act as a poor proxy for code, we just let you write code.

Marketplace

There are a huge range of both free and premium pre-built themes which you can download from the Ghost Theme Marketplace:

Theme development

Ghost themes are written with a templating language called handlebars, which has a set of dynamic helpers to insert your data into template files. For example: {{author.name}} outputs the name of the current author.

The best way to learn how to write your own Ghost theme is to have a look at the source code for Casper, which is heavily commented and should give you a sense of how everything fits together.

  • default.hbs is the main template file, all contexts will load inside this file unless specifically told to use a different template.
  • post.hbs is the file used in the context of viewing a post.
  • index.hbs is the file used in the context of viewing the home page.
  • and so on

We've got full and extensive theme documentation which outlines every template file, context and helper that you can use. You can also get started with our useful starter theme, which includes the most common foundations and components required to build your own theme.

If you want to chat with other people making Ghost themes to get any advice or help, there's also a themes section on our public Ghost forum.

posts.html:
Work with your existing tools

It's possible to connect your Ghost site to hundreds of the most popular apps and tools using integrations that take no more than a few minutes to setup.

Whether you need to automate workflows, connect your email list, build a community or embed products from your ecommerce store, our integrations library has got it all covered with hundreds of tutorials.

Zapier

On top of this, you can connect your Ghost site to more than 1,000 external services using the official integration with Zapier.

Zapier sets up automations with Triggers and Actions, which allows you to create and customise a wide range of connected applications.

Example: When someone new subscribes to a newsletter on a Ghost site (Trigger) then the contact information is automatically pushed into MailChimp (Action).

Here are the most popular Ghost<>Zapier automation templates:

Custom integrations

At the heart of Ghost sits a robust JSON API designed to create, manage and retrieve content with ease.

It's possible to create custom Ghost integrations with dedicated API keys and webhooks from the Integrations page within Ghost Admin.

Beyond that, the API allows you to build entirely custom publishing apps. You can send content from your favourite desktop editor, build a custom interface for handling editorial workflow or use Ghost as a full headless CMS with a custom front-end.

The Ghost API is thoroughly documented and straightforward to work with for developers of almost any level.

Final step: Themes

Alright, on to the last post in our welcome-series! If you're curious about creating your own Ghost theme from scratch, find out how that works.

posts.html:
Sensible tagging

You can think of tags like Gmail labels. By tagging posts with one or more keyword, you can organise articles into buckets of related content.

When you create content for your publication you can assign tags to help differentiate between categories of content.

For example you may tag some content with News and other content with Podcast, which would create two distinct categories of content listed on /tag/news/ and /tag/podcast/, respectively.

If you tag a post with both News and Podcast - then it appears in both sections. Tag archives are like dedicated home-pages for each category of content that you have. They have their own pages, their own RSS feeds, and can support their own cover images and meta data.

The primary tag

Inside the Ghost editor, you can drag and drop tags into a specific order. The first tag in the list is always given the most importance, and some themes will only display the primary tag (the first tag in the list) by default.

News, Technology, Startup

So you can add the most important tag which you want to show up in your theme, but also add related tags which are less important.

Private tags

Sometimes you may want to assign a post a specific tag, but you don't necessarily want that tag appearing in the theme or creating an archive page. In Ghost, hashtags are private and can be used for special styling.

For example, if you sometimes publish posts with video content - you might want your theme to adapt and get rid of the sidebar for these posts, to give more space for an embedded video to fill the screen. In this case, you could use private tags to tell your theme what to do.

News, #video

Here, the theme would assign the post publicly displayed tags of News - but it would also keep a private record of the post being tagged with #video. In your theme, you could then look for private tags conditionally and give them special formatting.

You can find documentation for theme development techniques like this and many more over on Ghost's extensive theme docs.

Dynamic routing

Dynamic routing gives you the ultimate freedom to build a custom publication to suit your needs. Routes are rules that map URL patterns to your content and templates.

You may not want content tagged with News to exist on: example.com/tag/news. Instead, you want it to exist on example.com/news .

In this case you can use dynamic routes to create customised collections of content on your site. It's also possible to use multiple templates in your theme to render each content type differently.

There are lots of use cases for dynamic routing with Ghost, here are a few common examples:

  • Setting a custom home page with its own template
  • Having separate content hubs for blog and podcast, that render differently, and have custom RSS feeds to support two types of content
  • Creating a founders column as a unique view, by filtering content created by specific authors
  • Including dates in permalinks for your posts
  • Setting posts to have a URL relative to their primary tag like example.com/europe/story-title/
Dynamic routing can be configured in Ghost using YAML files. Read our dynamic routing documentation for further details.

Next: Apps & Integrations

Work with all your favourite apps and tools using our integrations, or create your own custom integrations with webhooks.

posts.html:
Make your site private

If you've got a publication that you don't want the world to see yet because it's not ready to launch, you can hide your Ghost site behind a basic shared pass-phrase.

You can toggle this preference on at the bottom of Ghost's General Settings:

Ghost will give you a short, randomly generated pass-phrase which you can share with anyone who needs access to the site while you're working on it. While this setting is enabled, all search engine optimisation features will be switched off to help keep your site under the radar.

Do remember though, this is not secure authentication. You shouldn't rely on this feature for protecting important private data. It's just a simple, shared pass-phrase for some very basic privacy.

Invite your team

Ghost has a number of different user roles for your team:

Contributors
This is the base user level in Ghost. Contributors can create and edit their own draft posts, but they are unable to edit drafts of others or publish posts. Contributors are untrusted users with the most basic access to your publication.

Authors
Authors are the 2nd user level in Ghost. Authors can write, edit and publish their own posts. Authors are trusted users. If you don't trust users to be allowed to publish their own posts, they should be set as Contributors.

Editors
Editors are the 3rd user level in Ghost. Editors can do everything that an Author can do, but they can also edit and publish the posts of others - as well as their own. Editors can also invite new Contributors & Authors to the site.

Administrators
The top user level in Ghost is Administrator. Again, administrators can do everything that Authors and Editors can do, but they can also edit all site settings and data, not just content. Additionally, administrators have full access to invite, manage or remove any other user of the site.

The Owner
There is only ever one owner of a Ghost site. The owner is a special user which has all the same permissions as an Administrator, but with two exceptions: The Owner can never be deleted. And in some circumstances the owner will have access to additional special settings if applicable. For example: billing details, if using Ghost(Pro).

It's a good idea to ask all of your users to fill out their user profiles, including bio and social links. These will populate rich structured data for posts and generally create more opportunities for themes to fully populate their design.

Next: Organising content

Find out how to organise your content with sensible tags and authors, or for more advanced configurations, how to create custom content structures using dynamic routing.
posts.plaintext:
Make your site private
If you've got a publication that you don't want the world to see yet because
it's not ready to launch, you can hide your Ghost site behind a basic shared
pass-phrase.

You can toggle this preference on at the bottom of Ghost's General Settings:

Ghost will give you a short, randomly generated pass-phrase which you can share
with anyone who needs access to the site while you're working on it. While this
setting is enabled, all search engine optimisation features will be switched off
to help keep your site under the radar.

Do remember though, this is not secure authentication. You shouldn't rely on
this feature for protecting important private data. It's just a simple, shared
pass-phrase for some very basic privacy.

Invite your team 
Ghost has a number of different user roles for your team:

Contributors
This is the base user level in Ghost. Contributors can create and edit their own
draft posts, but they are unable to edit drafts of others or publish posts.
Contributors are untrusted users with the most basic access to your publication.

Authors
Authors are the 2nd user level in Ghost. Authors can write, edit and publish
their own posts. Authors are trusted users. If you don't trust users to be
allowed to publish their own posts, they should be set as Contributors.

Editors
Editors are the 3rd user level in Ghost. Editors can do everything that an
Author can do, but they can also edit and publish the posts of others - as well
as their own. Editors can also invite new Contributors & Authors to the site.

Administrators
The top user level in Ghost is Administrator. Again, administrators can do
everything that Authors and Editors can do, but they can also edit all site
settings and data, not just content. Additionally, administrators have full
access to invite, manage or remove any other user of the site.

The Owner
There is only ever one owner of a Ghost site. The owner is a special user which
has all the same permissions as an Administrator, but with two exceptions: The
Owner can never be deleted. And in some circumstances the owner will have access
to additional special settings if applicable. For example: billing details, if
using Ghost(Pro) [https://ghost.org/pricing/].

> It's a good idea to ask all of your users to fill out their user profiles,
including bio and social links. These will populate rich structured data for
posts and generally create more opportunities for themes to fully populate their
design.
Next: Organising content
Find out how to organise your content [/organising-content/] with sensible tags
and authors, or for more advanced configurations, how to create custom content
structures using dynamic routing.
posts.custom_excerpt: There are a couple of things to do next while you're getting set up: making your site private and inviting your team.

posts.title: Publishing options
posts.html:
Distribute your content

Access the post settings menu by clicking the settings icon in the top right hand corner of the editor and discover everything you need to get your content ready for publishing. This is where you can edit things like tags, post URL, publish date and custom meta data.

Feature images, URL & excerpts

Insert your post feature image from the very top of the post settings menu. Consider resizing or optimising your image first to ensure it's an appropriate size. Below this, you can set your post URL, publish date and add a custom excerpt.

Tags & authors

You can easily add multiple tags and authors to any post to filter and organise the relationships between your content in Ghost.

Structured data & SEO

There's no need to hard code your meta data. In fact, Ghost will generate default meta data automatically using the content in your post.

Alternatively, you can override this by adding a custom meta title and description, as well as unique information for social media sharing cards on Facebook and Twitter.

It's also possible to set custom canonicals, which is useful for guest posts or curated lists of external links.

Ghost will automatically implement structured data for your publication using JSON-LD to further optimise your content.

{
    "@context": "https://schema.org",
    "@type": "Article",
    "publisher": {
        "@type": "Organization",
        "name": "Publishing options",
        "logo": "https://static.ghost.org/ghost-logo.svg"
    },
    "author": {
        "@type": "Person",
        "name": "Ghost",
        "url": "http://demo.ghost.io/author/ghost/",
        "sameAs": []
    },
    "headline": "Publishing options",
    "url": "http://demo.ghost.io/publishing-options",
    "datePublished": "2018-08-08T11:44:00.000Z",
    "dateModified": "2018-08-09T12:06:21.000Z",
    "keywords": "Getting Started",
    "description": "The Ghost editor has everything you need to fully optimise your content. This is where you can add tags and authors, feature a post, or turn a post into a page."
}

You can test that the structured data schema on your site is working as it should using Googles structured data tool.

Code injection

This tool allows you to inject code on a per post or page basis, or across your entire site. This means you can modify CSS, add unique tracking codes, or add other scripts to the head or foot of your publication without making edits to your theme files.

To add code site-wide, use the code injection tool in the main admin menu. This is useful for adding a Google Analytics tracking code, or to start tracking with any other analytics tool.

To add code to a post or page, use the code injection tool within the post settings menu. This is useful if you want to add art direction, scripts or styles that are only applicable to one post or page.

Next: Admin settings

Now you understand how to create and optimise content, let's explore some admin settings so you can invite your team and start collaborating.

posts.title: Writing posts with Ghost
posts.html:
Just start writing

Ghost has a powerful visual editor with familiar formatting options, as well as the ability to add dynamic content.

Select your text to add formatting such as headers or to create links. Or use Markdown shortcuts to do the work for you - if that's your thing.

Rich editing at your fingertips

The editor can also handle rich media objects, called cards, which can be organised and re-ordered using drag and drop.

You can insert a card either by clicking the + button, or typing / on a new line to search for a particular card. This allows you to efficiently insert images, markdown, html, embeds and more.

For example:

  • Insert a video from YouTube directly by pasting the URL
  • Create unique content like buttons or forms using the HTML card
  • Need to share some code? Embed code blocks directly 
<header class="site-header outer">
    <div class="inner">
        {{> "site-nav"}}
    </div>
</header>

It's also possible to share links from across the web in a visual way using bookmark cards that automatically render information from a websites meta data. Paste any URL to try it out:

Working with images in posts

You can add images to your posts in many ways:

  • Upload from your computer
  • Click and drag an image into the browser
  • Paste directly into the editor from your clipboard
  • Insert using a URL

Image sizes

Once inserted you can blend images beautifully into your content at different sizes and add captions and alt tags wherever needed.

Image galleries

Tell visual stories using the gallery card to add up to 9 images that will display as a responsive image gallery:

Image optimisation

Ghost will automatically resize and optimise your images with lossless compression. Your posts will be fully optimised for the web without any extra effort on your part.

Next: Publishing Options

Once your post is looking good, you'll want to use the publishing options to ensure it gets distributed in the right places, with custom meta data, feature images and more.

posts.html:
A few things you should know

  1. Ghost is designed for ambitious, professional publishers who want to actively build a business around their content. That's who it works best for.
  2. The entire platform can be modified and customised to suit your needs. It's very powerful, but does require some knowledge of code. Ghost is not necessarily a good platform for beginners or people who just want a simple personal blog.
  3. It's possible to work with all your favourite tools and apps with hundreds of integrations to speed up your workflows, connect email lists, build communities and much more.

Behind the scenes

Ghost is made by an independent non-profit organisation called the Ghost Foundation. We are 100% self funded by revenue from our Ghost(Pro) service, and every penny we make is re-invested into funding further development of free, open source technology for modern publishing.

The version of Ghost you are looking at right now would not have been made possible without generous contributions from the open source community.

Next up, the editor

The main thing you'll want to read about next is probably: the Ghost editor. This is where the good stuff happens.

By the way, once you're done reading, you can simply delete the default Ghost user from your team to remove all of these introductory posts!

posts.html:
A lot of disparate ideas pass through my head on a daily basis. They're chaotic, which is giving me a somewhat murky mind.

I've tried freeform journaling in the past, each page a raw stream of consciousness filled with random drawings and doodles and private desires. Right now I'm seeking something more structured to gather my thoughts hence this new blog. A key ingredient for me right now is that these posts will be public, which will be a forcing function for me to think properly before hitting publish, so that this blog is a more structured record of my thoughts about the world.

I plan to cover a broad range of topics. For now, the name of the blog is Sensatez, a Spanish word meaning sanity and sensibility. I'll be writing about politics, philosophy, science, technology, music, ethics, and other topics on my mind. Over time, I may find a groove and narrow the blog's focus somewhat, but for now, Sensatez is a broad mental scaffold to keep my disparate musings from clouding my head.
posts.plaintext:
A lot of disparate ideas pass through my head on a daily basis. They're chaotic,
which is giving me a somewhat murky mind.

I've tried freeform journaling in the past, each page a raw stream of
consciousness filled with random drawings and doodles and private desires. Right
now I'm seeking something more structured to gather my thoughts  hence this new
blog. A key ingredient for me right now is that these posts will be public,
which will be a forcing function for me to think properly before hitting publish
, so that this blog is a more structured record of my thoughts about the world.

I plan to cover a broad range of topics. For now, the name of the blog is 
Sensatez, a Spanish word meaning sanity and sensibility. I'll be writing about
politics, philosophy, science, technology, music, ethics, and other topics on my
mind. Over time, I may find a groove and narrow the blog's focus somewhat, but
for now, Sensatez is a broad mental scaffold to keep my disparate musings from
clouding my head.

posts.html:
Chopin's Nocturnes are perfect, pinnacle human expression.

Every art form has its peak output, a work so unparalleled in beauty and form that all other practitioners live in its shadow. All philosophy is a series of footnotes to Plato. No great basketball player since Michael Jordan's reign has ever escaped the incessant comparisons. And good luck publishing a physics manuscript after Isaas Newton dropped Principia in 1687 and invented calculus and the laws of motion.

To me, Chopin's Nocturnes are in this god-tier category a work so emotionally resonant and sublimely human that all subsequent attempts must be seen through its lens. All piano melodies feel derivative by comparison. It's like the whole solo-piano repertoire is simply a subset of Chopin's expansive genius.
posts.plaintext:
Chopin's Nocturnes [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-gDinVAmtA0] are perfect,
pinnacle human expression.

Every art form has its peak output, a work so unparalleled in beauty and form
that all other practitioners live in its shadow. All philosophy is a series of
footnotes to Plato
[https://www.college.columbia.edu/core/content/whitehead-plato]. No great
basketball player since Michael Jordan's reign has ever escaped the incessant
comparisons. And good luck publishing a physics manuscript after Isaas Newton
dropped Principia
[https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Philosophi%C3%A6_Naturalis_Principia_Mathematica] 
in 1687 and invented calculus and the laws of motion.

To me, Chopin's Nocturnes are in this god-tier category  a work so emotionally
resonant and sublimely human that all subsequent attempts must be seen through
its lens. All piano melodies feel derivative by comparison. It's like the whole
solo-piano repertoire is simply a subset of Chopin's expansive genius.

posts.title: Fonts for sheet music?

And the process of expressing written music through an instrument is much more of a technical exercise in timing and precision than simply reading. posts.html:
Why is there not an equivalent of typographical fonts for sheet music? Different sheet books and score sites print musical staff notation in subtly different ways, but there's a surprisingly small amount of variability. Where are the legibility tweaks, the creative interpretations, the artistic flare?

Certainly words are more varied and versatile, more omnipresent in our daily experience, than the treble and bass clef. And the process of expressing written music through an instrument is much more of a technical exercise in timing and precision than simply reading. But the sheer lack of flare and variability in musical notation is still somewhat surprising. Different fonts have different legibility characteristics, invoke wildly different aesthetic feelings, and speak volumes about the presenter's intent. If musical notation were renderable in a similarly broad array of forms, I'm sure musical subcultures would form preferences for different styles, and musical expression would become that much richer and more interesting.

For what it's worth, I personally fine MuseScore's staff notation on the printed page to be subtly superior to other styles I've seen, for it's legibility and clarity. But I wish there were a richer vocabulary and broader variability around these style differences in musical notation, just like we have for letters and numbers.
posts.plaintext:
Why is there not an equivalent of typographical fonts
[https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Font] for sheet music? Different sheet books and
score sites print musical staff notation in subtly different ways, but there's a
surprisingly small amount of variability. Where are the legibility tweaks, the
creative interpretations, the artistic flare?

Certainly words are more varied and versatile, more omnipresent in our daily
experience, than the treble and bass clef. And the process of expressing written
music through an instrument is much more of a technical exercise in timing and
precision than simply reading. But the sheer lack of flare and variability in
musical notation is still somewhat surprising. Different fonts have different
legibility characteristics, invoke wildly different aesthetic feelings, and
speak volumes about the presenter's intent. If musical notation were renderable
in a similarly broad array of forms, I'm sure musical subcultures would form
preferences for different styles, and musical expression would become that much
richer and more interesting.

For what it's worth, I personally fine MuseScore's [https://musescore.org/] 
staff notation on the printed page to be subtly superior to other styles I've
seen, for it's legibility and clarity. But I wish there were a richer vocabulary
and broader variability around these style differences in musical notation, just
like we have for letters and numbers.

posts.html:
Almost everyone I know, myself included, will support Joe Biden in November with a bit of regret. It feels like electing a septuagenarian who's been in government since the actual 70's is a bit of a missed opportunity.

But goddamn if I will not do everything I can to get this man in power. I don't think our country can survive another four years of orange terror. It's truly an existential election, and I don't say that lightly.

I'm tired of having to care what's happening on Twitter. I'm tired of knowing that US Foreign Policy could do a 180 shift and gear up for war, all because one man got triggered. I'm tired of feeling like I have to be paying attention every day.

I for one can't wait to have a president I don't think about for weeks at a time. I'm deeply looking forward to having a boring president. Let's embrace Boring Biden and all do everything we can to get him elected!

Almost everyone I know, myself included, will support Joe Biden in November with
a bit of regret. It feels like electing a septuagenarian who's been in
government since the actual 70's is a bit of a missed opportunity.

But goddamn if I will not do everything I can to get this man in power. I don't
think our country can survive another four years of orange terror. It's truly an
existential election, and I don't say that lightly.

I'm tired of having to care what's happening on Twitter. I'm tired of knowing
that US Foreign Policy could do a 180 shift and gear up for war, all because
one man got triggered. I'm tired of feeling like I have to be paying attention
every day.

I for one can't wait to have a president I don't think about for weeks at a
time. I'm deeply looking forward to having a boring president. Let's embrace 
Boring Biden and all do everything we can to get him elected!

posts.html:
I think in 30 years we'll look back at the founding of Facebook the way we look back at the first McDonald's a technology-gone-wrong tale of good intentions and bad incentives causing a deeply addictive health epidemic.

It's now well-understood that Twitter, Facebook and Instagram have caused massive problems not just for the health of our political systems, but also for the mental health of our society. We're 15 years into this social media experiment, and it's not going particularly well, is it?

The deep divisions and disruptions caused by social media should be a learning opportunity for the tech community, to reassess some of their core principles. We need to wrestle with this question:

Looking forward, how do we avoid such a massive mistake from happening again in the next society-shifting technology innovation be it Virtual Reality, Bioengineering, Weaponized Drones, or Artificial Intelligence?

I don't think anyone knows the answers to this question yet, but we know getting it right is of critical importance. The next technology dystopia could be far worse than social media be it an engineered pandemic 100x more deadly than COVID-19, or an AI that decides its creator species is more of a nuisance than an aid to its ultimate goals.

Avoiding dystopian outcomes with each successive wave of new technology is likely to become harder and harder. The physicists working on the Manhattan Project understood the dark implications of their work, but Mark Zuckerberg still seems unwilling to grapple with the real-world consequences of his.

Here are a few broad areas we should focus on going forward:

Art is a critical antidote to the excesses of technology. I think Black Mirror has done more than anything else recently to open the world's eyes to the possibility of human frailty to cause deeply disturbing technology futures. We need more art of all kinds music, literature, television, film, sculpture, poetry to remind us of our human fallibility and open our eyes to the possibility for unintended consequences.

Technology Ethics needs to become more sophisticated, and we need mechanisms to bake in better incentives to our technology system. No doubt our social media ecosystem would be far healthier if it weren't heavily incentivized to maximize time-on-site to serve ads. Governments are struggling to solve this problem with existing social-media giants, but in some sense it's too late. We should have baked better incentives into the structure of our technologies from the beginning.

Tech-forward government is critical for avoiding perverse incentives on the next tech frontier. Why is there not a government agency in Washington focused on these issues, and staffed with highly competent technologists? Instead, the only tech-forward parts of our government are the organizations like the NSA that are tasked with stealing the citizens's private information.

Philosophy is critical in these challenging times. The maturity of our thinking around technology will always be a function of the maturity of the individuals involved. We need to foster a culture of intellectual maturity, that draws on ancient wisdom rather than thin and immature hedonistic "follow your bliss" mindsets. I'm heartened by the fact that Twitter's CEO Jack Dorsey spends weeks at a time in silent meditation. I'm glad deep thinkers like Sam Harris and Tristan Harris are popular among the tech crowd. More of this.

None of this is easy, but we must keep negotiating this problem before it's too late. Let's become more clear-eyed about human frailty and our increasing power of destruction. Let's stop using the term "disruption" in the tech community as if it's an obvious force for good. Let's each look inward and integrate our own potential for destruction before we invent the most powerful technologies in human history.

posts.html:
An experiment in community, philosophy and self-improvement

Were living in a time of disconnection and isolation. And on top of that, powerful forces like Twitter's character limit and the 24-hour news cycle mean that our culture is often incredibly shallow our conversations on important issues often lack emotional and intellectual depth.

Stoic philosophy offers a deep, rich and time-tested antidote to these ills.

A Stoic Circle is a small intentional community of 6-8 people that meets each week to discuss a single principle from the Stoic philosophers. We seek to apply the lessons of the Stoics into our own lives. Part group therapy, part philosophy discussion, part self-help circle, its an intentional community that strives to go beneath the surface to get at the deep emotional issues we face in our lives.

Values inside the Circle

When we enter the circle each week, we choose to embody the following values:

  • Self-improvement We strive to improve ourselves. We actively encourage this mindset in those around us. We seek to avoid negative or unproductive thought patterns and recognize that growth is a never-ending game.
  • Openness We value honesty and transparency, and are willing to speak frankly about our own inner lives. We try to look deeply within ourselves in order to recognize, articulate and share our own insecurities, weaknesses and self-doubts, as well as our inner triumphs and victories over fear.

Format of the Circle

A Stoic Circle consists of a 1 hour meeting per week for 6 weeks. For now this will be on Zoom to facilitate social distancing.

Each week we will discuss a single short excerpt from the Stoic philosophers, and a few related prompts to provoke discussion. Here is the six week syllabus:

Week I Avoiding outrage

Choose not to be harmed and you wont feel harmed. Dont feel harmed and you havent been. ~ Marcus Aurelius
  • Have you observed any negative impacts in your life from the emotion of outrage?
  • Outrage is addictive. What habits or behaviors do you engage in that provoke your outrage? What are some techniques for avoiding this?

Week II Self-discipline

Be tolerant with others and strict with yourself. ~ Marcus Aurelius
  • It's easy to look out at the world and cast judgement. Have you found yourself able to resist this urge? If so, have you found this to be beneficial?
  • Share a story of a time when you managed to stay disciplined towards a healthy intention you set, and how this improved your life.

Week III The value of time

People are frugal in guarding their personal property; but as soon as it comes to squandering time they are most wasteful of the one thing in which it is right to be stingy. ~ Seneca
  • Are there areas of your life you're spending more time on than you think ideal? Do you suffer from any addictions or compulsions that eat away at your time but that you're unable to abstain from?
  • What approaches do you have for evaluating whether different activities are worth your time?

Week IV Facing mortality

You could leave life right now. Let that determine what you do and say and think. ~ Marcus Aurelius
He who fears death will never do anything worthy of a man who is alive. ~ Seneca
  • How have you integrated the knowledge of your own mortality into your life? Has this been a positive or negative experience?
  • Do you fear death? If so, are you able to introspect deeper to understand what you truly fear? For example, perhaps you fear being forgotten by the world, or you fear the uncertainty of an afterlife.

Week V Focus on your sphere of control

The chief task in life is simply this: to identify and separate matters so that I can say clearly to myself which are externals not under my control, and which have to do with the choices I actually control. Where then do I look for good and evil? Not to uncontrollable externals, but within myself to the choices that are my own. ~ Epictetus
  • Share a time when you've managed to adjust your approach after realizing you were trying to "over-control" a situation, and how that benefited you.
  • Sometimes being successful requires a "leap of faith" that perhaps you can control more than you thought possible. How can we embrace ambition without focusing on things outside our control? Or are these two ideas really in tension?

Week VI True Wealth

Wealth consists not in having great possessions, but in having few wants. ~ Epictetus
  • Are there any physical possessions that you're particularly attached to? How if at all have these attachments limited your freedom or mental health?
  • What are some techniques for limiting our true desires to only what we know will truly bring us fulfillment?

posts.html:
A lot of things are deeply strange about having all of human knowledge available at our fingertips.

Our societies are still convulsing over the massive shocks this has had on our cultural and political systems. But much of the impact from the internet on our lives is felt not at the societal-scale, but much closer to home. This is the first post in a series I'm planning, to explore about the intimate psychological effects caused by the internet.

Today's post is on a phenomenon I'm calling "The Wikipedia Effect"

The Wikipedia Effect The subtle sense of deflation and disillusionment felt after reading the Wikipedia article for a new concept.

The feeling may come from realizing that your new idea is not as novel as you thought. Or it may be because Wikipedia managed to break apart a work you found beautiful into its component parts in a way that is precisely correct yet wholly dissatisfying.

Like schadenfreude or hygge, this emotion is complex to pin down. I'll try to illustrate it more clearly with a few examples.

  • I've recently been very engrossed in listening to and attempting to play Chopin's Nocturnes. The Wikipedia article slices up their form into such a concise phrase that it left me feeling dumb. "The nocturnes are generally set in ternary form (ABA), featuring a melancholy mood, and a clear melody floating over a left-hand accompaniment of arpeggios or broken chords. Repetitions of the main theme generally add increasingly ornate embellishments" TODO: Drafting and explanation
  • TODO: More examples

A lot of things are deeply strange about having all of human knowledge available
at our fingertips.

Our societies are still convulsing over the massive shocks this has had on our
cultural and political systems. But much of the impact from the internet on our
lives is felt not at the societal-scale, but much closer to home. This is the
first post in a series I'm planning, to explore about the intimate psychological
effects caused by the internet.

Today's post is on a phenomenon I'm calling "The Wikipedia Effect"

> The Wikipedia Effect  The subtle sense of deflation and disillusionment felt
after reading the Wikipedia article for a new concept.
The feeling may come from realizing that your new idea is not as novel as you
thought. Or it may be because Wikipedia managed to break apart a work you found
beautiful into its component parts in a way that is precisely correct yet wholly
dissatisfying.

Like schadenfreude [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Schadenfreude] or hygge
[https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hygge], this emotion is complex to pin down. I'll
try to illustrate it more clearly with a few examples.

 * I've recently been very engrossed in listening to and attempting to play 
   Chopin's Nocturnes [/chopins-nocturnes/]. The Wikipedia article slices up
   their form into such a concise phrase that it left me feeling dumb. "The
   nocturnes are generally set in ternary form (ABA), featuring a melancholy
   mood, and a clear melody floating over a left-hand accompaniment of arpeggios
   or broken chords. Repetitions of the main theme generally add increasingly
   ornate embellishments" TODO: Drafting and explanation
